metadata.case_name: Aravali Golf Club (Haryana Tourism Corporation) v. Respondents (Plaintiffs)

facts.text: Plaintiffs-respondents were appointed as Mali (gardener) on daily wages in the service of defendant-appellant Aravali Golf Club run by Haryana Tourism Corporation in 1989 and 1988 respectively.
In 1989, plaintiffs-respondents were told to perform duties of Tractor Drivers though there was no post of tractor driver in the employer's establishment.
Plaintiffs-respondents continued to be paid wages for the post of Mali for a number of years.
On recommendation by Head Office, appellants started paying plaintiffs-respondents wages of tractor driver on daily wage basis as per rates recommended by Deputy Commissioner.
Plaintiffs-respondents continued to work as tractor drivers for about a decade.
Services of plaintiffs-respondents regularized against the post of Mali in 1999, no post as tractor driver.
Despite representations, grievance not redressed; respondents filed civil suit in April 2001 claiming regularization against posts of tractor driver.
Trial Court rejected claim, observed no post of tractor driver, plying tractor part and parcel of Mali job in Golf Club; suit dismissed.
First Appellate Court (Additional District Judge, Faridabad) accepted appeal, set aside Trial Court judgment, directed defendants to get post of tractor driver sanctioned and regularize plaintiffs.
High Court Single Judge in R.S.A. No.666/2006 dated 17.02.2006 affirmed First Appellate Court, held post of tractor driver should be created, no hitch, dismissed second appeal.
Plaintiff No.1 (respondent No.1) appointed as Mali daily wage on 09.10.1989.
Respondent No.1 filed Writ Petition No.6216/1991 for regularization; High Court disposed directing representation against termination, restrained termination till decided.
Respondent No.1 made representation on 02.05.1991; informed on 14.05.1991 no post of tractor driver, case considered when sanctioned post available.
Plaintiff No.1 paid wages of tractor driver from August 1990 to 11.05.1999 on daily wage DC rate.
Services of plaintiff No.1 regularized as Mali on 11.05.1999, accepted without protest.
Plaintiff No.2 (respondent No.2) engaged as Mali daily wage w.e.f. 01.09.1988, regularized as Mali on 11.05.1999.
No sanctioned post of tractor driver in appellants' establishment.
Trial Court recorded finding of fact: no sanctioned post of tractor driver, plaintiffs cannot be regularized; finding not disputed.

legal_issues.text: Whether courts can direct creation of posts of tractor driver where no sanctioned post exists and regularize services of respondents thereon.
Limits of judicial power vis-a-vis executive/legislative functions like creation of posts.

petitioner_arguments.text: There is no sanctioned post of tractor driver, hence no question of regularizing respondents thereon.
Courts cannot direct creation of posts, which is executive/legislative prerogative involving economic factors.
Trial Court finding of no sanctioned post is fact, not disturbed; lower courts exceeded jurisdiction.

respondent_arguments.text: Respondents working as tractor drivers since 13.08.1989, entitled to regularization as such.

court_reasoning.text: No sanctioned post of tractor driver exists; respondents' counsel unable to show any.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Direction to create post and regularize beyond jurisdiction of courts.

court_reasoning.text: Creation and sanction of posts is prerogative of executive/legislative authorities; courts cannot arrogate this function.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Involves economic factors; courts pointed this repeatedly.

court_reasoning.text: Judges must exercise restraint, not encroach into executive/legislative domain; separation of powers essential.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial activism cannot cross limits into other organs' functions.

holdings.text: Courts cannot direct creation of posts or regularization against non-existent posts.
Judiciary must respect separation of powers, exercise restraint, not perform executive/legislative functions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Drugs & Pharmaceuticals Ltd. v. Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Judges cannot cross limits into executive/legislative functions.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.C. Chandra v. State of Jharkhand
Tata Cellular v. Union of India
Ram Jawaya v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Constitution differentiates functions, no assumption by one organ of another's.

precedents_cited.case_name: Asif Hameed v. State of J&K
precedents_cited.relevance: Organs function in demarcated spheres; judicial review within limits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Deoki Nandan Aggarwal
V.K. Reddy v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Judges should not play role of law makers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suresh Seth v. Commissioner, Indore Municipal Corpn.
precedents_cited.relevance: Court cannot direct legislature to make law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bal Ram Bali v. Union of India

precedents_cited.relevance: Pendency of cases shows judiciary's own delays.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Expanded scope via judicial decisions; but ordinarily for legislature/executive.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments of High Court and First Appellate Court set aside; Trial Court judgment upheld; suit dismissed. No costs.

key_quotes.text: The Court cannot direct the creation of posts. Creation and sanction of posts is a prerogative of the executive or legislative authorities.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Judges must exercise judicial restraint and must not encroach into the executive or legislative domain.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the name of judicial activism Judges cannot cross their limits and try to take over functions which belong to another organ of the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court
